p:
Studies conducted in recent decades have identified a number of genes and variants associated with PD
4– 12 . It is estimated that 5–10% of all PD cases have a genetic etiology linked to forms with monogenic Mendelian inheritance patterns. These forms are attributed to various loci containing genes, such as SNCA, PRKN, PARK7, and LRRK2 (refs.
13– 15 ). In the rest of the cases, called sporadic, genetic susceptibility factors have also been demonstrated. So far, >90 risk loci have been identified; the associated variants are mainly single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)
5, 8, 10, 12, 14 . Some of these SNPs are located within or very close to loci linked to the familial forms mentioned above, which indicates that changes in the sequence of these genes are likely to be implicated in the key biological processes of PD development
14, 16 . The identification and functional characterization of these genetic changes have provided information on the cellular and subcellular mechanisms contributing to PD-related neurodegeneration
15– 21 .
